title: 1  Lecture 1: Understanding Levels of Measurement
text:
1.1 Discussion
Each of those pieces of information has a different kind of structure. Some are just categories, others have an order, and some are numerical with real measurements. To analyze them correctly, we need to know what level of measurement they belong to.

title: 1  Lecture 1: Understanding Levels of Measurement
text:
1.2 The Four Levels of Measurement

1.2.1 Nominal (Name Only)
These are just labels — categories with no inherent order.
Examples - Type of crime (Assault, Theft, Fraud)
- Neighborhood (Downtown, North End, Eastside)
- Season (Fall, Summer)
Can we say that ‘Fraud’ is more than ‘Assault’? No — they’re just different categories.
But what if we say it was “more violent”?


1.2.2 Ordinal (Order Matters, But Spacing Doesn’t)
These have a meaningful order, but the distance between ranks isn’t consistent.
Examples - Trust in the police (1 = Poor, 2 = Somewhat, 3= Not Sure, 4= Sort of, 5 = Excellent)
- Crime severity (Low, Moderate, High)
- Level of fear of crime (Low, Medium, High)
Is a ‘High’ severity crime exactly three times worse than a ‘Low’ one? Probably not.
What about trust in the police?


1.2.3 Interval/Ratio (Equal Spacing)
Here the units are consistent, so the values are meaningful.
Examples - Number of arrests - Incident response time (minutes) - Property damage (dollars) - Victim age
If one officer took 10 minutes and another took 20, can we say one took twice as long? Yes — because zero means none.
Can we say there are half as many crimes in a neighborhood compared to another?
Note: if the variable has a true zero point, then it is called a ratio level of measurement.

title: 1  Lecture 1: Understanding Levels of Measurement
text:
1.4 So what?
Why does it matter to know the level of measurement?

It determines which statistical tools we can use
It shapes how we interpret averages or differences
It helps us understand what our numbers actually represent

title: 2  Lecture 2: Frequency Distributions and Levels of Measurement
text:
2.1 Scenario
In criminology, we often start with a question about people’s attitudes or experiences and then use data to describe what we find. Suppose we want to answer this question: How much public support is there for expanding rehabilitation programs for people in prison?
To begin answering this, suppose we ask 10 people the following survey question: “How much do you support expanding rehabilitation programs for people in prison?”, where the response options were: 1 = Strongly oppose, 2 = Oppose, 3 = Support, 4 = Strongly support.

2.2 Tools
Remember our research question: How much public support is there for expanding rehabilitation programs for people in prison?
Our goal is to describe what the data tells us. What are some things we could describe about the data based on this table?
Now, let’s identify some of the tools we can use and what they can tell us.

2.2.1 Frequencies
The frequency, \(f\), tells us how many people chose each response. To get the frequency, we just count up each instance of a response category:

2.2.2 Proportions
Proportion, \(p\), represents the fraction of the total that each category represents, \(p = \frac{f}{N}\), where \(N\) represents the total number of cases. (A quick note on symbols: for now we will use \(N\) to refer to the total number of cases in our data. When we discuss samples and populations we will agument this and use \(n\) to refer to the size of a sample and \(N\) to refer to the size of a population).
